The new Student Council constitution was passed unanimously

the Council. The draft must now
go to Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, Dean
of the Homewood Schools, and
to Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Director
of Student Activities for final approval before being submitted to
the student body.

New Schedule Set
For Greek Squeak;
Register March 16
The fifth annual fraternity
sing, sponsored by the Hopkins
Glee Club, has been re-scheduled
for April 13 at the ROTC Building, and the registration fee dateline has been moved to March
16, according to Co-chairmen
Gene Coakley and Jim Michael.
"There is more interest in the
sing than in past years. Boys from
several fraternities, even ones
which didn't participate last year,
are showing a lot of interest,"
Michael said, in urging participation of all fraternities. Thus
far, Phi Sig, Phi Psi, DU and
Beta, who finished first last year,
have won.
There will be no admission
charge to the sing, which will be
followed by dancing. Beer and
pretzels will be served and everyone is invited, stag or drag.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 2, 1956

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Student campus policemen have
been laid off "because (the plant
manager's office) felt that the
traffic control was at a point
where their services were no longer required on a regular basis,"
according to Assistant Plant Manager Joseph Geiger.
Geiger went on to explain that
"there will be occasions where it
will be necessary, due to activities
on the campus that will warrant
additional men, to supplement our
regular force; at that time we will
call on these men again." In the
interim, traffic is being directed
by the regular campus policemen.
Concerning the towing away of
illegally parked cars, Geiger said,
"I feel that the new method of
enforcing the Campus Parking
and Traffic regulations has been
highly successful, and although
the means of enforcement are
rather drastic, we have the backing of most everyone."
"Excellent results" have been
achieved "insofar as keeping roads
and loading areas 'clear of cars.
There has been a decided decrease
in the number of parking violations since the new rules and regulations went into effect last November 28," Geiger added.
On Tuesday, a News-Letter
traffic count revealed at least 35
cars illegally parked, on islands,
lawns, and campus roads. Campus traffic regulations provide
that such cars be towed away;
however, no policemen were seen
ticketing the cars.

Weigel To Address
JHU Assembly In March

Service Exam Set; Father
Deadline March 5
Hopkins students interested in
taking the Selective Service College Qualification Test have until
midnight March 5, to submit applications.
To be eligible to apply for the
test, scheduled to be given April
19, a student must intend to request deferment as a student,
must satisfactorily pursue a fulltime course of instruction, and
must not have previously taken
the test. A student who has
reached the age of Selective Service registration (18) may take
the test; one who has received
and filed his draft board questionnaire is strongly urged to take it.
Applications may be obtained
at any Selective Service board.

Would-be Teacher
Given Instruction
Professor J. M. Stephens of the
Education Department announced
Friday that it is now possible for
Hopkins students to major in
secondary school teaching.
The purpose of this new department is to permit students who
are interested in teaching to meet
all of the professional requirements without interfering with
their academic preparation.

— Mixer —
Transportation to the Hood
College Mixer will leave Levering Hall at 6:45 p.m. tomorrow
night. The total cost will be
$1.15 if the bus is filled. Ques-,,
tions should be directed to Jim
Young, Box 713 or AT 4-3215.

Band To Present
Shriver Program
Friday, March 16
JHU's Band will present a concert in Shriver Hall on March 16,
President Reid Gaskins announced this week.
The concert will feature "On
the Trail," "Buglers' Holiday",
and will have several marches and
a few novelty numbers throughout the program. Gaskins stated
that this year's band has been
"as good as, or better than any
other year's. The guys in the
band really enjoy playing."
Marching in the Cherry Blossom Parade, Homecoming, and
playing at all the lacrosse games
will round off the JHU Band's
schedule for this year. Homecoming will see the band with the
Glee Club to put on a program.
"Of course, we'll be busy almost
all day," stated Gaskins concerning Homecoming.
Other dates released by Gaskins
include the weekend of April 28,
when the Hopkins organization
travels to West Point to play at
the Hopkins-Army lacrosse game.
On May 12, the band will go to
Annapolis with the lacrosse team
who plays Navy.
Gaskins stated, "The band has
been building up for the past few
years. Since I've been here, the
band has been getting better, and
this year is no exception."

NEWS-LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 2, 1956

• • . There Was The Word, Visitors To Throng
And The Word Was With ... To ODK's Conclave
BY GORDON SCHOCHET
Centered about the second semester and "post exam week,"
the current issue of The
Word,
publication of the JHU Veterans
Club, leads off with a list of
recommended "Krazy Kourses for
Kool Kats."
Outstanding among the courses
suggested by the editors are Labor
Cases (meets in maternity ward,
Johns Hopkins Hospital), Very Independent Study (room 302, Fontainebleau Hotel, Miami, Fla.),
Fluid Studies (meets at Kay's
Cabaret), and Private Finance
(each student brings own money,
dice, and cards). Courses
suggested to liberal arts majors include Advanced Illiteracy, Applied
Mediocrity, Illogical Methodology,
ano Esoteric
Nebulisms.
Filling otherwise blank spaces
at the bottoms
of pages is a collection of archaic and often
Pilfered (but footnoted) "jokes"
and
cartoons. Such offerings set the
Style for the
publication with the
exception of two articles concerned with a petition for a
higher veterans'
bonus bill and a Veterans Club-sponsored book
drive
for Asiatic students.

In the "Gin Mill and Culture
Column," four local night spots
are described by Jim Pfafflin and
John Cooper. The commentaries
advise the club's members of
where to go and where not to go:
One of the "cabarets" is described
as follows: "The less said about
this place the better; in the words
of the venerable bard, 'a clippeth
joint.' . The unwise vet will discover that the unattached women
have a penchant for becoming attached to his wallet."

Dick Abraham of Bell Telephone Laboratories, here experimenti
with closing the loop on a transistor feedback amplifier.

"I'm working with top names and top talent"
That's one of Richard P. Abraham's
commerits about his career with Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N. J.
In 1954, after I'd received my M.S.from
Stanford," Dick continues, "I was interviewed by a number of companies. Of
these I liked the Bell Labs interview best
—the interviewer knew what he was talking about, and the Labs seemed a highcaliber place.
"The Labs have a professional atmosphere, and I'm really impressed by my
working associates. As for my work, I've
been on rotating assignments—working
with transistor networks and their measurement techniques, studying magnetic

drum circuitry, and doing classified work
on Nike. This experience is tremendous.
"In addition to the job, I attend Labconducted classes on a graduate level
several times a week. Besides that, the
Labs are helping me get a Ph.D. at
Columbia by giving me time off to get to
late afternoon classes. That's the kind of
co-operation you really appreciate from
your company.
"What are important to me are the opportunities offered by the job and the
work itself. My wife and I own a house
near Murray Hill, and we've found a lot
of friends through the Labs. All in all,
I think I'm in the right kind of place."

Dick Abraham is typical of the many young men
who are finding their careers in the Bell System.
Similar career opportunities exist in the Bell
Telephone Companies, Western Electric and
Sandia Corporation. Your placement officer has
more information about these companies.

Atlantic
Middle
With
the
Championships only a week away,
the varsity fencing team plays
host to Lehigh University tomorrow afternoon in the final meet
of the season in the ROTC building at 2 p.m.
Coach Cal Schlick expects this
to be the toughest match since
the Navy contest. The Middies are
the only team to have turned back
the Jays thus far. He stated that
"they have a good coach, good
material, and have won most of
their matches by very decisive
scores. I expect to see a better
class of fencers than we have for
the most part this season, and
the boys will really have to be on
their toes to handle it."
Last Saturday afternon, the
Blue Jay fencers met and beat a
visiting Haverford College team
by the lop-sided score of 18-9. According to Schlick, "the greatest
single factor in the victory was
the spirit of the team Which
seemed to sort of overwhelm the
opposition. Even the substitutes
caught it and turned in victories
in their bouts."
Hopkins captured all three
classes- of the match, taking the

foil 5-4, the epee 7-2, and the
sabre 6-3. Dick Everett began to
shape up to pre-season predictions. Everett turned in three successive victories in his event.
Howie Pierce and Fred Rosenbloom each recorded 1-2 slates in
the event.
Schlick praised Tom Feher's
performance in the epee. Tom
emerged victorious in two bouts
before making way for a substitute. Mark Zequeira, who substituted for him, won the third. Joe
Rivkin, 1-1; Sid Miller, 1-0; and
Al Rose, 2-1; rounded out the
scoring for Hopkins in the event.
Captain John Forte continued
his winning ways in the sabre,
coming out on top twice, without
a setback. Joe Fetsch substituted
for him in the third bout and
kept the winning streak going.
Fetsch, as Schlick pointed out, is
a victim of circumstances. He is

inexperienced and up against experienced teammates in that weapon of the fencing team 'which
ranks highest. Thus far, Joe has
been in four bouts and won all of
them. Darryl Carter and Dick
Heckman turned in 2-1 and 1-2
records respectively in the Sabre
event.
Since each man must go 36
bouts, top conditioning is of the
utmost importance. Only one man
from Hopkins will participate in
each weapon. Forte looks like a
sure bet to go in the sabre, while
Everett will most likely get the go
ahead sign in the foil.

New Schedule Set
For Greek Squeak;
Register March 16
The fifth annual fraternity
sing, sponsored by the Hopkins
Glee Club, has been re-scheduled
for April 13 at the ROTC Building, and the registration fee dateline has been moved to March
16, according to Co-chairmen
Gene Coakley and Jim Michael.
"There is more interest in the
sing than in past years. Boys from
several fraternities, even ones
which didn't participate last year,
are showing a lot of interest,"
Michael said, in urging participation of all fraternities. Thus
far, Phi Sig, Phi Psi, DU and
Beta, who finished first last year,
have won.
There will be no admission
charge to the sing, which will be
followed by dancing. Beer and
pretzels will be served and everyone is invited, stag or drag.

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Student campus policemen have
been laid off "because (the plant
manager's office) felt that the
traffic control was at a point
where their services were no longer required on a regular basis,"
according to Assistant Plant Manager Joseph Geiger.
Geiger went on to explain that
"there will be occasions where it
will be necessary, due to activities
on the campus that will warrant
additional men, to supplement our
regular force; at that time we will
call on these men again." In the
interim, traffic is being directed
by the regular campus policemen.
Concerning the towing away of
illegally parked cars, Geiger said,
"I feel that the new method of
enforcing the Campus Parking
and Traffic regulations has been
highly successful, and although
the means of enforcement are
rather drastic, we have the backing of most everyone."
"Excellent results" have been
achieved "insofar as keeping roads
and loading areas 'clear of cars.
There has been a decided decrease
in the number of parking violations since the new rules and regulations went into effect last November 28," Geiger added.
On Tuesday, a News-Letter
traffic count revealed at least 35
cars illegally parked, on islands,
lawns, and campus roads. Campus traffic regulations provide
that such cars be towed away;
however, no policemen were seen
ticketing the cars.

Weigel To Address
JHU Assembly In March

Service Exam Set; Father
Deadline March 5
Hopkins students interested in
taking the Selective Service College Qualification Test have until
midnight March 5, to submit applications.
To be eligible to apply for the
test, scheduled to be given April
19, a student must intend to request deferment as a student,
must satisfactorily pursue a fulltime course of instruction, and
must not have previously taken
the test. A student who has
reached the age of Selective Service registration (18) may take
the test; one who has received
and filed his draft board questionnaire is strongly urged to take it.
Applications may be obtained
at any Selective Service board.

Would-be Teacher
Given Instruction
Professor J. M. Stephens of the
Education Department announced
Friday that it is now possible for
Hopkins students to major in
secondary school teaching.
The purpose of this new department is to permit students who
are interested in teaching to meet
all of the professional requirements without interfering with
their academic preparation.

— Mixer —
Transportation to the Hood
College Mixer will leave Levering Hall at 6:45 p.m. tomorrow
night. The total cost will be
$1.15 if the bus is filled. Ques-,,
tions should be directed to Jim
Young, Box 713 or AT 4-3215.

Band To Present
Shriver Program
Friday, March 16
JHU's Band will present a concert in Shriver Hall on March 16,
President Reid Gaskins announced this week.
The concert will feature "On
the Trail," "Buglers' Holiday",
and will have several marches and
a few novelty numbers throughout the program. Gaskins stated
that this year's band has been
"as good as, or better than any
other year's. The guys in the
band really enjoy playing."
Marching in the Cherry Blossom Parade, Homecoming, and
playing at all the lacrosse games
will round off the JHU Band's
schedule for this year. Homecoming will see the band with the
Glee Club to put on a program.
"Of course, we'll be busy almost
all day," stated Gaskins concerning Homecoming.
Other dates released by Gaskins
include the weekend of April 28,
when the Hopkins organization
travels to West Point to play at
the Hopkins-Army lacrosse game.
On May 12, the band will go to
Annapolis with the lacrosse team
who plays Navy.
Gaskins stated, "The band has
been building up for the past few
years. Since I've been here, the
band has been getting better, and
this year is no exception."

BY GORDON SCHOCHET
Centered about the second semester and "post exam week,"
the current issue of The
Word,
publication of the JHU Veterans
Club, leads off with a list of
recommended "Krazy Kourses for
Kool Kats."
Outstanding among the courses
suggested by the editors are Labor
Cases (meets in maternity ward,
Johns Hopkins Hospital), Very Independent Study (room 302, Fontainebleau Hotel, Miami, Fla.),
Fluid Studies (meets at Kay's
Cabaret), and Private Finance
(each student brings own money,
dice, and cards). Courses
suggested to liberal arts majors include Advanced Illiteracy, Applied
Mediocrity, Illogical Methodology,
ano Esoteric
Nebulisms.
Filling otherwise blank spaces
at the bottoms
of pages is a collection of archaic and often
Pilfered (but footnoted) "jokes"
and
cartoons. Such offerings set the
Style for the
publication with the
exception of two articles concerned with a petition for a
higher veterans'
bonus bill and a Veterans Club-sponsored book
drive
for Asiatic students.

In the "Gin Mill and Culture
Column," four local night spots
are described by Jim Pfafflin and
John Cooper. The commentaries
advise the club's members of
where to go and where not to go:
One of the "cabarets" is described
as follows: "The less said about
this place the better; in the words
of the venerable bard, 'a clippeth
joint.' . The unwise vet will discover that the unattached women
have a penchant for becoming attached to his wallet."

Dick Abraham of Bell Telephone Laboratories, here experimenti
with closing the loop on a transistor feedback amplifier.

"I'm working with top names and top talent"
That's one of Richard P. Abraham's
commerits about his career with Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N. J.
In 1954, after I'd received my M.S.from
Stanford," Dick continues, "I was interviewed by a number of companies. Of
these I liked the Bell Labs interview best
—the interviewer knew what he was talking about, and the Labs seemed a highcaliber place.
"The Labs have a professional atmosphere, and I'm really impressed by my
working associates. As for my work, I've
been on rotating assignments—working
with transistor networks and their measurement techniques, studying magnetic

drum circuitry, and doing classified work
on Nike. This experience is tremendous.
"In addition to the job, I attend Labconducted classes on a graduate level
several times a week. Besides that, the
Labs are helping me get a Ph.D. at
Columbia by giving me time off to get to
late afternoon classes. That's the kind of
co-operation you really appreciate from
your company.
"What are important to me are the opportunities offered by the job and the
work itself. My wife and I own a house
near Murray Hill, and we've found a lot
of friends through the Labs. All in all,
I think I'm in the right kind of place."

Dick Abraham is typical of the many young men
who are finding their careers in the Bell System.
Similar career opportunities exist in the Bell
Telephone Companies, Western Electric and
Sandia Corporation. Your placement officer has
more information about these companies.

Atlantic
Middle
With
the
Championships only a week away,
the varsity fencing team plays
host to Lehigh University tomorrow afternoon in the final meet
of the season in the ROTC building at 2 p.m.
Coach Cal Schlick expects this
to be the toughest match since
the Navy contest. The Middies are
the only team to have turned back
the Jays thus far. He stated that
"they have a good coach, good
material, and have won most of
their matches by very decisive
scores. I expect to see a better
class of fencers than we have for
the most part this season, and
the boys will really have to be on
their toes to handle it."
Last Saturday afternon, the
Blue Jay fencers met and beat a
visiting Haverford College team
by the lop-sided score of 18-9. According to Schlick, "the greatest
single factor in the victory was
the spirit of the team Which
seemed to sort of overwhelm the
opposition. Even the substitutes
caught it and turned in victories
in their bouts."
Hopkins captured all three
classes- of the match, taking the

foil 5-4, the epee 7-2, and the
sabre 6-3. Dick Everett began to
shape up to pre-season predictions. Everett turned in three successive victories in his event.
Howie Pierce and Fred Rosenbloom each recorded 1-2 slates in
the event.
Schlick praised Tom Feher's
performance in the epee. Tom
emerged victorious in two bouts
before making way for a substitute. Mark Zequeira, who substituted for him, won the third. Joe
Rivkin, 1-1; Sid Miller, 1-0; and
Al Rose, 2-1; rounded out the
scoring for Hopkins in the event.
Captain John Forte continued
his winning ways in the sabre,
coming out on top twice, without
a setback. Joe Fetsch substituted
for him in the third bout and
kept the winning streak going.
Fetsch, as Schlick pointed out, is
a victim of circumstances. He is

inexperienced and up against experienced teammates in that weapon of the fencing team 'which
ranks highest. Thus far, Joe has
been in four bouts and won all of
them. Darryl Carter and Dick
Heckman turned in 2-1 and 1-2
records respectively in the Sabre
event.
Since each man must go 36
bouts, top conditioning is of the
utmost importance. Only one man
from Hopkins will participate in
each weapon. Forte looks like a
sure bet to go in the sabre, while
Everett will most likely get the go
ahead sign in the foil.
